column4: Dutch health authorities to cancel 43,000 vaccination appointments due to decision on Astrazeneca - ANP
column5: The Netherlands on Sunday joined a fast-growing list of countries suspending use of AstraZeneca's (AZN.L) COVID-19 vaccine after reports of unexpected possible side effects from the injection.
column6: The vaccine will not be used until at least March 29 as a precaution, the Dutch government said in a statement.
column7: The announcement will lead to delays in rolling out shots in the Netherlands, which had pre-ordered 12 million doses of AstraZeneca's vaccine.
column8: Health authorities had scheduled around 290,000 AstraZeneca injections in the coming two weeks.
column9: The move, which follows a similar decision by Ireland earlier in the day, is based on reports from Denmark and Norway of possible serious side effects, the government said. read more
column10: Three health workers in Norway who had recently received the vaccine were being treated in hospital for bleeding, blood clots and a low count of blood platelets, Norwegian health authorities said on Saturday. read more
column11: No such cases had been found yet in the Netherlands, the Dutch Health ministry said, adding there was no proof yet of a direct link between the vaccine and the reports from Denmark and Norway.
column12: "We can't allow any doubts about the vaccine," Dutch Health minister Hugo de Jonge said.
column13: "We have to make sure everything is right, so it is wise to pause for now."
column14: AstraZeneca said on Sunday a review of safety data of people vaccinated with its COVID-19 vaccine has shown no evidence of an increased risk of blood clots. read more
column15: Late last week, the Dutch government said there was no reason to stop using the AstraZeneca vaccine, as the EMA said there was no indication it could cause blood clots.
column16: But De Jonge said his decision was informed by new reports, which would now be investigated by the European Medicines Agency (EMA).
column17: Along with Denmark, Norway and Ireland, Iceland has also suspended the use of the vaccine over clotting issues, while Thailand became the first country outside of Europe to do so on Friday.
column18: Italy's northern region of Piedmont on Sunday said it would stop using a batch of AstraZeneca vaccines after a teacher died following his vaccination on Saturday. Austria also stopped using a particular batch last week. read more

column4: U.S. administers 107.1 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines: CDC
column5: (Reuters) - The United States has administered 107,060,274 doses of COVID-19 vaccines in the country and distributed 135,847,835 doses as of Sunday, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said.
column6: The tally is for Moderna, Pfizer/BioNTech and Johnson & Johnson’s vaccines as of 6 a.m. ET (1000 GMT) on Sunday, the agency said.
column7: According to the tally posted on March 13, the agency had administered 105,703,501 doses of the vaccines and distributed 135,846,665 doses.
column8: The agency said 69,784,210 people had received at least one dose, while 37,459,269 people were fully vaccinated.
column9: A total of 7,547,477 vaccine doses have been administered in long-term care facilities, the agency said.

column4: U.S. administers 105.7 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines: CDC
column5: (Reuters) - The United States has administered 105,703,501 doses of COVID-19 vaccines in the country and distributed 135,846,665 doses as of Saturday, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said.
column6: The tally is for Moderna, Pfizer/BioNTech, and Johnson & Johnson’s vaccines as of 6:00 a.m. ET on Saturday, the agency said.
column7: According to the tally posted on March 12, the agency had administered 101,128,005 doses of the vaccines and distributed 133,337,525 doses.
column8: The agency said 68,884,011 people had received at least one dose, while 36,929,777 people were fully vaccinated.
column9: A total of 7,538,985 vaccine doses have been administered in long-term care facilities, the agency said.

column4: U.S. administers 101.1 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines: CDC
column5: (Reuters) - The United States has administered 101,128,005 doses of COVID-19 vaccines in the country and distributed 133,337,525 doses as of Friday morning, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said.
column6: The tally is for Moderna, Pfizer/BioNTech, and Johnson & Johnson’s vaccines as of 6:00 a.m. ET on Friday, the agency said.
column7: According to the tally posted on March 11, the agency had administered 98,203,893 doses of the vaccines and distributed 131,131,470 doses.
column8: The agency said 65,965,305 people had received at least one dose, while 35,000,159 people were fully vaccinated.
column9: A total of 7,499,822 vaccine doses have been administered in long-term care facilities, the agency said.

column4: France approves J&J's Janssen COVID-19 vaccine
column5: PARIS (Reuters) - France’s health regulator said on Friday it had approved Johnson & Johnson’s single-dose COVID-19 vaccine for use in France, a day after it was approved by the European Union authorities.
column6: “The COVID-19 Janssen vaccine can be used on people from the age of 18 ... within the framework of the French vaccination strategy, including for people aged 65 and older and who might have illnesses,” the Haute Autorite de Sante (HAS) said in a statement.
column7: HAS said the vaccine was efficient and well tolerated by patients. It will be the fourth vaccine on the French market.
column8: The European Medicines agency (EMA) approved the Johnson & Johnson vaccine on Thursday, paving the way for the first shots to be delivered in a month.

column4: Italy's medicines agency approves J&J's COVID-19 vaccine
column5: MILAN (Reuters) - Italy’s medicines agency AIFA said on Friday it has approved the use of the COVID-19 vaccine produced by Johnson & Johnson, following the green light from European drugs regulator (EMA) on Thursday.
column6: The vaccine is the fourth to be endorsed for use in the European Union after vaccines from Pfizer-BioNTech,, AstraZeneca-Oxford University and Moderna, and is recommended for those over 18 years of age. It’s the first single-dose COVID-19 vaccine.
column7: “This is the fourth vaccine to be available with the important additional advantage of a single dose and ease of administration, therefore ideal for the setting of family doctors. From mid-April, an important reality,” said AIFA’s general director Nicola Magrini in the agency’s website.
column8: The Italian agency said it confirmed the EMA’s assessment of the vaccine’s efficacy, which reaches up to 77% 14 days after administration and 85% 28 days after administration.

column4: WHO approves J&J's COVID-19 vaccine for emergency listing
column5: GENEVA (Reuters) - The World Health Organization on Friday approved the emergency listing of Johnson & Johnson’s COVID-19 vaccine, giving its seal of approval to expedite use especially in countries with weaker regulatory agencies.
column6: It is the third COVID-19 vaccine after the two-shot regimens of Pfizer/BioNTech and AstraZeneca to receive backing from the WHO, and the first requiring just a single injection.
column7: The listing covers use in all countries, for roll-out of the vaccine facility COVAX and follows the European Medicines Agency (EMA) authorisation announcement on Thursday.
column8: “Every new, safe and effective tool against COVID-19 is another step closer to controlling the pandemic,” WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said in a statement.
column9: “Emergency use listing is the greenlight for a vaccine to be procured and rolled out by COVAX,” he told a news conference.
column10: WHO is convening its strategic advisory group of immunisation experts next week to draw up recommendations on its use, he added.
column11: “But the hope offered by these tools will not materialise unless they are made available to all people in all countries,” he said.
column12: The WHO also welcomed the one-shot administration as facilitating vaccination logistics.
column13: WHO senior adviser Bruce Aylward said that the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, which does not require an ultra cold chain, was “even better suited to some of the countries that are worst-hit, affected by the pandemic”.
column14: COVAX, co-run with the Gavi vaccine alliance, has an agreement for more than 500 million doses of the J&J vaccine, Aylward said.
column15: “What we are trying to do is work with the company to bring that forward as early as possible. And we are hoping by at least July that we have access to doses that we can be rolling out, if not even earlier.”
column16: J&J's chief scientist Paul Stoffels told Reuters on Thursday the company expects to produce up to 3 billion doses here of the vaccine next year, after previously pledging to deliver 1 billion globally by the end of 2021.
column17: The WHO said that, under an emergency-use listing, companies have to commit to generate further safety and efficacy data to enable full licensing.

column4: France approves Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine - BFM TV
column5: France's health regulator said on Friday it had approved Johnson & Johnson's (JNJ.N)single-dose COVID-19 vaccine for use in France, a day after it was approved by the European Union authorities.
column6: "The COVID-19 Janssen vaccine can be used on people from the age of 18 ... within the framework of the French vaccination strategy, including for people aged 65 and older and who might have illnesses," the Haute Autorite de Sante (HAS) said in a statement.
column7: HAS said the vaccine was efficient and well tolerated by patients. It will be the fourth vaccine on the French market.
column8: The European Medicines agency (EMA) approved the Johnson & Johnson vaccine on Thursday, paving the way for the first shots to be delivered in a month. read more

column4: WHO's Aylward hopes to have J&J vaccine in COVAX scheme by at least July
column5: GENEVA (Reuters) - The World Health Organization hopes to have doses of Johnson & Johnson’s COVID-19 vaccine for use in the COVAX vaccine-sharing scheme by at least July, WHO Senior Adviser Bruce Aylward said on Friday.
column6: “COVAX has an agreement for 500 million doses, we are trying to work with the company to bring that forward, we’re hoping at least by July that we have access to doses we can be rolling out, if not even earlier,” Aylward said.
column7: Aylward also said the vaccine was even better suited to some of the countries that are worst-hit by the virus, as it is a single dose and doesn’t require an ultra-cold chain environment.

column4: WHO's Aylward hopes to have J&J vaccine in COVAX scheme by at least July
column5: The World Health Organization hopes to have doses of Johnson & Johnson's (JNJ.N) COVID-19 vaccine for use in the COVAX vaccine-sharing scheme by at least July, WHO Senior Adviser Bruce Aylward said on Friday.
column6: "COVAX has an agreement for 500 million doses, we are trying to work with the company to bring that forward, we're hoping at least by July that we have access to doses we can be rolling out, if not even earlier," Aylward said.
column7: Aylward also said the vaccine was even better suited to some of the countries that are worst-hit by the virus, as it is a single dose and doesn't require an ultra-cold chain environment.

column4: UPDATE 1-S.Africa's Aspen Pharmacare to supply J&J's COVID-19 vaccine by end-June
column5: (Adds details from interview, background)
column6: JOHANNESBURG, March 12 (Reuters) - Aspen Pharmacare plans to start supplying Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine doses from its facility in South Africa before the end of June, its chief executive said on Friday.
column7: Stephen Saad told Reuters in an interview that the technology transfer from J&J has “gone very well, and we are now committing (to) commercial supply in our financial year”, which ends June 30.
column8: Aspen’s production timeline for the vaccine is critical for South Africa as the country is relying heavily on J&J’s doses to inoculate a significant portion of the 40 million people it is targeting to reach so-called herd immunity.
column9: Health experts have indicated that if the vaccines for South Africa are supplied directly from Aspen’s facility it would save costs and could speed up vaccine roll-out.
column10: The country is already the worst hit in Africa mainly due to a spike in coronavirus infections seen in December and January, led by a more contagious variant of the virus.
column11: J&J’s vaccine was shown to be 89% effective at preventing severe disease in the South African leg of a big global trial.
column12: South Africa has signed an agreement for 11 million J&J doses with an option to get another 20 million, its Health Minister Zweli Mkhize has said, but it is not clear how many of the doses will come from Aspen.
column13: Saad said that will depend on the negotiations between African governments and J&J but said he hoped a chunk of its supply could meet the demand from South Africa and the rest of the continent.
column14: Aspen has committed to supplying 300 million COVID-19 vaccine doses, though the final amount that will be manufactured will depend on demand from J&J, Saad said.
column15: He said the company has a capacity to manufacture 600 million doses of vaccines in South Africa, but there had been no discussions with J&J or any other company to manufacture more COVID-19 vaccines beyond the committed number. (Reporting by Promit Mukherjee; Editing by Jason Neely and Jan Harvey)

column4: S.Africa's Aspen Pharmacare to supply J&J's COVID-19 vaccine by end-June
column5: JOHANNESBURG (Reuters) - Aspen Pharmacare plans to start supplying Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine doses from its facility in South Africa before the end of June, its chief executive said on Friday.
column6: Stephen Saad told Reuters in an interview that the technology transfer from J&J has “gone very well and we are now committing commercial supply in our financial year.”
column7: The company’s financial year ends in June.
column8: The company has committed 300 million COVID-19 vaccine doses, however the final amount that will be manufactured will depend on demand from J&J, he said.

column4: South Africa could get 20 million more J&J vaccine doses, minister says
column5: CAPE TOWN (Reuters) - The South African government’s agreement with Johnson & Johnson for 11 million COVID-19 vaccine doses includes an option for an additional 20 million doses depending on the availability of stock, its health minister said.
column6: “The agreement has been signed off for 11million doses with an option for an additional 20m doses based on availability of stock,” Minister Zweli Mkhize said in a written reply to a question from a lawmaker seen by Reuters on Friday.
column7: The country kicked off its vaccination campaign last month with J&J’s single-dose vaccine after suspending plans to administer AstraZeneca’s double-dose vaccine.
column8: A small trial showed the AstraZeneca shot offered minimal protection against mild to moderate illness from the dominant local coronavirus variant.
column9: The J&J shot is being given to up to 500,000 healthcare workers in a research study to further evaluate it in the field before a larger-scale rollout is expected to start in the second quarter. Local pharmaceutical company Aspen will be manufacturing J&J doses under licence.
column10: Mkhize added in his written reply that the J&J vaccine was cost-effective for reasons including that it is effective against the 501Y.V2 variant first identified in South Africa late last year, it is stored at fridge temperature and it is a single-dose vaccine.

column4: South Africa could get 20 mln more J&J vaccine doses, health minister says
column5: The South African government's agreement with Johnson & Johnson for 11 million COVID-19 vaccine doses includes an option for an additional 20 million doses depending on the availability of stock, Health Minister Zweli Mkhize said in a written reply to a question from a lawmaker seen by Reuters on Friday.

column4: U.S. administers 98.2 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines: CDC
column5: (Reuters) - The United States has administered 98,203,893 doses of COVID-19 vaccines in the country and distributed 131,131,470 doses as of Thursday morning, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said.
column6: The tally is for Moderna, Pfizer/BioNTech, and Johnson & Johnson’s vaccines as of 6:00 a.m. ET on Thursday, the agency said.
column7: According to the tally posted on March 10, the agency had administered 95,721,290 doses of the vaccines, and distributed 127,869,155 doses.
column8: The agency said 64,071,674 people had received at least one dose, while 33,863,127 people were fully vaccinated.
column9: A total of 7,473,597 vaccine doses have been administered in long-term care facilities, the agency said.

column4: J&J to make up to three billion COVID-19 vaccines in 2022: chief scientist
column5: CHICAGO/FRANKFURT (Reuters) - Johnson & Johnson’s chief scientist said the company expects to produce up to 3 billion doses of its COVID-19 vaccine next year, after the European Union approved the one-shot immunization on Thursday.
column6: The company is bringing on three manufacturing plants to produce the key drug substance. It also will have seven plants globally that will handle final production steps and bottling into vials known as fill and finish.
column7: “All these will function together to deliver the 1 billion by the end of the year,” Dr. Paul Stoffels, J&J’s chief scientific officer, said in an interview.
column8: “Next year, we can do more than two billion vaccines, and even up to three if we maximize capacity. With Merck on board, we will be north of 2 billion,” he added, referring to a recent agreement for rival Merck & Co to produce J&J’s vaccine.
column9: Stoffels also said he was confident J&J will be able to deliver a planned 55 million doses to the European Union in the second quarter. An EU official told Reuters this week that J&J had flagged possible supply issues that may complicate these plans.
column10: “We trust that we can deliver close to that amount in Q2,” Stoffels said, adding that final production steps would be the biggest challenge.
column11: “It’s the fill and finish which was the critical part and there we learned we had later access, we started later and had later access to facilities,” he said.
column12: J&J’s shot is the fourth to be endorsed for use in the EU after vaccines from Pfizer/BioNTech, AstraZeneca Plc and Moderna Inc.
column13: Europe is scrambling to get immunization campaigns off the ground after an early supply shortfall from Pfizer, since resolved, and more persistent issues with AstraZeneca.
column14: J&J’s vaccine is expected to be used widely around the globe because of its one-shot convenience and logistical advantage of being shipped and stored at normal refrigerator temperatures. Both the Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna vaccines require two doses and must be shipped frozen.
column15: Thursday’s approval included authorization in Europe of Maryland-based Emergent Biosolutions Inc, which is making active drug substance for the vaccine.
column16: “Emergent is a very critical supplier. It’s important for both the U.S. and Europe and other parts of the world,” Stoffels said, adding it can deliver enough drug substance for “up to a billion vaccines a year.”
column17: Stoffels said in the United States, the company was only allowed to seek emergency use authorization for one manufacturing plant to produce drug substance.
column18: Initial U.S. doses are being made at the company’s plant in Leiden, the Netherlands. J&J is awaiting U.S. approvals of the Emergent plant for drug substance, and for Catalent Inc, a contract manufacturer that will handle fill and finish from a new manufacturing line in Bloomington, Indiana.
column19: Stoffels said as soon as J&J received U.S. authorization for the vaccine, U.S. regulators started reviewing the company’s additional production plants.
column20: He said early “hiccups” have been resolved and the company expects to deliver on its promise of 100 million doses before the end of June.
column21: In Europe, Stoffels said the company plans to significantly scale up production of its Leiden plant. Additional capacity will come on board likely over the summer, he added.
column22: Indian drugmaker Biological E Ltd will handle both drug substance and fill and finish for J&J’s vaccine. The company’s managing director told Reuters last month that Biological E was looking to contract manufacture roughly 600 million doses ofJ&J’s COVID-19 vaccine a year.
column23: Biological E is in the process of installing and validating equipment in the plant, which Stoffels said he expects to be ready in the second half of this year.

column4: Europe clears J&J's single-shot COVID-19 vaccine as roll-out falters
column5: (Reuters) - Europe approved Johnson & Johnson’s single dose COVID-19 vaccine on Thursday, paving the way for the first shots to be delivered in a month as the bloc seeks to speed up a stuttering inoculation campaign and boost its supplies.
column6: The COVID-19 shot is the fourth to be endorsed for use in the European Union after vaccines from Pfizer-BioNTech, AstraZeneca-Oxford University and Moderna, and is recommended for those over 18 years of age, the European Medicines agency (EMA) said. It’s the first single-dose COVID-19 vaccine.
column7: The United States, Canada and Bahrain have also approved the shot. South Africa is carrying out an expedited review.
column8: “With this latest positive opinion, authorities across the European Union will have another option to combat the pandemic and protect the lives and health of their citizens,” EMA’s Executive Director Emer Cooke said after the agency gave its conditional approval.
column9: The official nod came from the European Commission shortly after, the final step to allowing its use across the bloc.
column10: The region is having difficulty taming a spike in cases driven by a more contagious variant of the coronavirus, with countries including Italy and France imposing fresh lockdowns.
column11: J&J Chief Scientific Officer Paul Stoffels described it as a “landmark moment” for the U.S. drugmaker and the world as governments struggle to control the pandemic which has crushed economies and killed more than 2.7 million.
column12: The shot, called COVID Vaccine Janssen after the J&J unit that developed it, will help bulk up EU vaccine supplies after a faltering rollout due to delivery delays from Pfizer and AstraZeneca.
column13: The first shipments will start in the second half of April, the company said, adding it is committed to delivering at least 200 million doses to the EU this year.
column14: Exact volumes are not clear though and the U.S. drugmaker has told the European Union it is facing supply issues that may complicate plans to deliver the 55 million doses due in the second quarter in full.
column15: J&J’s factory in Leiden in the Netherlands and a plant in Baltimore in the United States run by Emergent BioSolutions have both been authorised by the drugs’ regulator as a manufacturer of ingredients for the vaccines.
column16: Earlier this year, some EU countries raised questions about J&J’s production network and contract with the EU, which would require it to send vaccines made at the Dutch factory to the United States for bottling before being shipped back to the EU.
column17: News that the EU had approved Johnson & Johnson’s vaccine came as Norway and Denmark temporarily suspended the use of AstraZeneca’s vaccine after reports of the formation of blood clots in some who have been vaccinated.
column18: In J&J’s 44,000-person global trial, the vaccine was found to be 66% effective at preventing moderate-to-severe COVID-19 four weeks after inoculation. It was 100% effective in preventing hospitalization and death due to the virus.
column19: In its statement on Thursday, the EMA said the vaccine was found to be 67% effective two weeks after inoculation.
column20: The side effects were usually mild or moderate and cleared within a couple of days after vaccination, it said. The most common ones were pain at the injection site, headache, tiredness, muscle pain and nausea.
column21: Though many rival shots have reported a higher protection rate, J&J’s vaccine could help boost thin EU supplies and simplify inoculation campaigns because it does not require a second dose or need to be shipped frozen.
column22: Direct comparison between headline numbers reported by different drugmakers is difficult because their trials had different goals, and J&J’s study was conducted while new, more contagious variants of the virus were circulating.
column23: Its vaccine delivers instructions for human cells to manufacture immunity-building proteins, using a weakened version of a common-cold virus to carry them in, similar to AstraZeneca’s shot, which uses a chimpanzee cold virus. J&J has also used the technology in its EU-approved Ebola vaccine.
column24: EU conditional marketing authorisation allows a treatment to be sold for a year without full data on its efficacy and side-effects being available.

column4: UPDATE 1-South Africa's Aspen Pharmacare reports 18% drop in half-year profit
column5: * Profit from continuing operations up 11%
column6: * Revenues up 17% led by demand for drugs
column7: * Tech transfer for J&J COVID-19 vaccine by Q2 (Adds details of COVID-19 vaccine, numbers)
column8: JOHANNESBURG, March 11 (Reuters) - Aspen Pharmacare said on Thursday its half-year profits were down 18% and that a technical transfer for manufacturing Johnson & Johnson’s COVID-19 vaccines will complete before June.
column9: The company said half-year total headline earnings per share (HEPS) were 566.2 cents, down from 689.7 cents reported in the same period a year ago, mainly on account of the sale of its European business which was concluded in November.
column10: HEPS from continuing operations increased by 11% to 571.0 cents, it said. HEPS is the main profit measure for South African companies.
column11: Aspen, which is Africa’s biggest pharmaceutical company, had said earlier in January that it would be manufacturing J&J’s COVID-19 vaccine by the end of March.
column12: “Technical transfer is expected to be completed during the second quarter of calendar year 2021 with commercial production contributing to our results toward the end of the current financial year,” the company said.
column13: The pharmaceutical company sells branded prescription drugs and over-the-counter medicines and sterile products or those that are directly administered into blood vessels.
column14: Its revenue for the six months to end December 2020 rose 17% to 18.6 billion rand, ($1.25 billion) led by its branded and manufacturing divisions.
column15: Most pharmaceutical companies took a hit last year on sales and profits as countries went into a lockdown hurting demand for prescription and over-the-counter products.
column16: But their shares have risen of late as people who had postponed elective or non-emergency procedures restarted doctor and hospital visits.
column17: Aspen’s shares, which hit a trough in March last year, have risen by more than 90%. Its shares closed up almost 1% against the broader index, which ended up 0.4% on Thursday.
column18: Aspen’s results were announced after the stock market closed. ($1 = 14.8847 rand) (Reporting by Promit Mukherjee; editing by Mfuneko Toyana and Jane Merriman)

column4: EU Commission gives final approval to J&J vaccine
column5: BRUSSELS, March 11 (Reuters) - The European Commission gave approval on Thursday for the use of Johnson & Johnson’s COVID-19 vaccine, the final step to allowing the European Union to use it across the bloc.
column6: “More safe and effective vaccines are coming to the market. We have just authorised the use of Johnson & Johnson’s vaccine in the EU, following EMA positive review,” Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission wrote on Twitter. (Reporting by Marine Strauss @StraussMarine, editing by Philip Blenkinsop)

column4: Factbox: Johnson & Johnson's COVID-19 vaccine recommended for EU authorization
column5: (Reuters) - The European Union’s drugs regulator on Thursday recommended conditionally approving Johnson & Johnson’s single dose COVID-19 vaccine, following authorizations in the United States and Canada.
column6: The following are details about J&J’s shot.
column7: Results from a trial of about 44,000 participants show the J&J vaccine was 66% effective in preventing moderate-to-severe COVID-19 globally.
column8: A review of available data by an independent safety monitoring board indicated that a single-dose of the COVID-19 vaccine was generally well-tolerated.
column9: In South Africa, where 95% of the cases in the trial were due to infection with the highly contagious B.1.351 coronavirus variant, the vaccine was 64% effective in preventing moderate-to-severe COVID-19 28 days after inoculation.
column10: About 6,000 people in South Africa took part in the trial.
column11: The level of protection from the vaccine against moderate-to-severe COVID-19 infection was 72% in the United States after 28 days.
column12: The shot was 66% effective at stopping moderate-to-severe cases in Brazil after 14 days and 68% after 28 days. It was 66% effective in Latin America overall, which involved nearly 18,000 people in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru.
column13: About 34% of trial participants were over age 60.
column14: 17.2% of participants in the trial were Black, 8.3% were American Indian or Alaskan Native, 2.5% were Asian and 45% were Hispanic or Latino.
column15: The FDA said the most common reactions were injection site pain at 48.6%, headache at 39%, fatigue at 38.2% and aches and pains at 33.2%. Other side effects included a fever in 9% of participants and a high fever in 0.2% of those who received the vaccine.
column16: The Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna vaccines use new messenger RNA technology to create an immune response and both require two shots. The one-shot J&J uses a common cold virus to introduce coronavirus proteins into cells to trigger an immune response.
column17: J&J’s vaccine remains stable for at least three months at normal refrigerator temperatures, while the Moderna vaccine must be shipped frozen and the Pfizer/BioNTech option must be shipped and stored at even colder sub-Arctic temperatures.
column18: Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna vaccines were about 94%-95% effective in trials conducted in the United States where variants were not circulating.
column19: Experts cautioned against drawing too much of a distinction between the mRNA and J&J vaccines because the trials had different endpoints and J&J’s was conducted while highly transmissible new variants of the virus were circulating.
column20: Novavax Inc, which is testing its vaccine in South Africa, said it was 60% effective at preventing mild, moderate and severe COVID-19 in patients who did not have HIV. It said about 90% of cases in the study involved the new South African variant. The mid-stage South Africa trial included 4,400 patients.
column21: The vaccine developed by AstraZeneca with Oxford University provided only minimal protection against mild-to-moderate COVID-19 from the South African variant in a relatively small trial. There was no data yet on its effectiveness in preventing severe disease in people who were infected by the variant.
column22: J&J expects to produce at least a billion doses of its vaccine in 2021 and has signed supply deals for most of that.
column23: The United States agreed to pay over $1 billion for 100 million doses, with an option to buy 200 million more. President Joe Biden on Wednesday directed his administration to procure 100 million more doses of the vaccine.
column24: J&J has committed to deliver 200 million doses of its vaccine to the EU this year, and the bloc has the option to buy 200 million more.
column25: Other deals include 22 million doses for Mexico, 9 million for Colombia, 30 million for the UK and 4 million to South Korea. It plans to supply 500 million to poorer countries, working with the COVAX alliance.
column26: South Africa has signed an agreement to secure 11 million doses.

column4: EU says formal authorisation of J&J vaccine to follow shortly
column5: BRUSSELS, March 11 (Reuters) - European Health Commissioner Stella Kyriakides said on Thursday the European Commission’s formal authorisation of Johnson & Johnson’s COVID-19 vaccine will follow shortly, after the EU’s drug regulator recommended granting it conditional marketing approval.
column6: “This marks another key step towards ensuring that all citizens can access safe and effective vaccinations as soon as possible. EU Commission authorisation will follow shortly,” Kyriakides wrote on Twitter. (Reporting by Marine Strauss @StraussMarine; editing by Philip Blenkinsop)

column4: FACTBOX-Johnson & Johnson's COVID-19 vaccine recommended for EU authorization
column5: The European Union's drugs regulator on Thursday recommended conditionally approving Johnson & Johnson's (JNJ.N) single dose COVID-19 vaccine, following authorizations in the United States and Canada. read more
column6: The following are details about J&J's shot.
column8: HOW EFFECTIVE WAS IT IN A LARGE STUDY?
column9: Results from a trial of about 44,000 participants show the J&J vaccine was 66% effective in preventing moderate-to-severe COVID-19 globally.
column10: A review of available data by an independent safety monitoring board indicated that a single-dose of the COVID-19 vaccine was generally well-tolerated.
column13: DATA IN SOUTH AFRICA
column14: In South Africa, where 95% of the cases in the trial were due to infection with the highly contagious B.1.351 coronavirus variant, the vaccine was 64% effective in preventing moderate-to-severe COVID-19 28 days after inoculation.
column15: About 6,000 people in South Africa took part in the trial.
column17: DATA IN UNITED STATES
column18: The level of protection from the vaccine against moderate-to-severe COVID-19 infection was 72% in the United States after 28 days.
column20: DATA IN LATIN AMERICA
column21: The shot was 66% effective at stopping moderate-to-severe cases in Brazil after 14 days and 68% after 28 days. It was 66% effective in Latin America overall, which involved nearly 18,000 people in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru.
column23: DEMOGRAPHICS
column24: About 34% of trial participants were over age 60.
column25: 17.2% of participants in the trial were Black, 8.3% were American Indian or Alaskan Native, 2.5% were Asian and 45% were Hispanic or Latino.
column27: SIDE EFFECTS
column28: The FDA said the most common reactions were injection site pain at 48.6%, headache at 39%, fatigue at 38.2% and aches and pains at 33.2%. Other side effects included a fever in 9% of participants and a high fever in 0.2% of those who received the vaccine.
column30: HOW DOES IT DIFFER FROM THE PFIZER AND MODERNA VACCINES?
column31: The Pfizer (PFE.N)/BioNTech and Moderna vaccines use new messenger RNA technology to create an immune response and both require two shots. The one-shot J&J uses a common cold virus to introduce coronavirus proteins into cells to trigger an immune response.
column32: J&J's vaccine remains stable for at least three months at normal refrigerator temperatures, while the Moderna vaccine must be shipped frozen and the Pfizer/BioNTech option must be shipped and stored at even colder sub-Arctic temperatures.
column35: HOW DOES IT RANK NEXT TO THE OTHERS?
column36: Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna vaccines were about 94%-95% effective in trials conducted in the United States where variants were not circulating.
column37: Experts cautioned against drawing too much of a distinction between the mRNA and J&J vaccines because the trials had different endpoints and J&J's was conducted while highly transmissible new variants of the virus were circulating.
column38: Novavax Inc (NVAX.O), which is testing its vaccine in South Africa, said it was 60% effective at preventing mild, moderate and severe COVID-19 in patients who did not have HIV. It said about 90% of cases in the study involved the new South African variant. The mid-stage South Africa trial included 4,400 patients.
column39: The vaccine developed by AstraZeneca (AZN.L) with Oxford University provided only minimal protection against mild-to-moderate COVID-19 from the South African variant in a relatively small trial. There was no data yet on its effectiveness in preventing severe disease in people who were infected by the variant.
column43: J&J expects to produce at least a billion doses of its vaccine in 2021 and has signed supply deals for most of that.
column44: The United States agreed to pay over $1 billion for 100 million doses, with an option to buy 200 million more. President Joe Biden on Wednesday directed his administration to procure 100 million more doses of the vaccine. read more
column45: J&J has committed to deliver 200 million doses of its vaccine to the EU this year, and the bloc has the option to buy 200 million more. read more
column46: Other deals include 22 million doses for Mexico, 9 million for Colombia, 30 million for the UK and 4 million to South Korea. It plans to supply 500 million to poorer countries, working with the COVAX alliance.
column47: South Africa has signed an agreement to secure 11 million doses. read more

column4: EU drugs regulator gives green light to J&J's single-shot COVID-19 vaccine
column5: Europe approved Johnson & Johnson's (JNJ.N) single dose COVID-19 vaccine on Thursday, paving the way for the first shots to be delivered in a month as the bloc seeks to speed up a stuttering inoculation campaign and boost its supplies.
column6: The COVID-19 shot is the fourth to be endorsed for use in the European Union after vaccines from Pfizer-BioNTech (PFE.N), (22UAy.DE), AstraZeneca-Oxford University (AZN.L) and Moderna (MRNA.O), and is recommended for those over 18 years of age, the European Medicines agency (EMA) said. It's the first single-dose COVID-19 vaccine.
column7: The United States, Canada and Bahrain have also approved the shot. South Africa is carrying out an expedited review. read more
column8: "With this latest positive opinion, authorities across the European Union will have another option to combat the pandemic and protect the lives and health of their citizens," EMA's Executive Director Emer Cooke said after the agency gave its conditional approval.
column9: The official nod came from the European Commission shortly after, the final step to allowing its use across the bloc.
column10: The region is having difficulty taming a spike in cases driven by a more contagious variant of the coronavirus, with countries including Italy and France imposing fresh lockdowns.
column11: J&J Chief Scientific Officer Paul Stoffels described it as a "landmark moment" for the U.S. drugmaker and the world as governments struggle to control the pandemic which has crushed economies and killed more than 2.7 million.
column12: The shot, called COVID Vaccine Janssen after the J&J unit that developed it, will help bulk up EU vaccine supplies after a faltering rollout due to delivery delays from Pfizer and AstraZeneca.
column13: The first shipments will start in the second half of April, the company said, adding it is committed to delivering at least 200 million doses to the EU this year.
column14: Exact volumes are not clear though and the U.S. drugmaker has told the European Union it is facing supply issues that may complicate plans to deliver the 55 million doses due in the second quarter in full. read more
column15: J&J's factory in Leiden in the Netherlands and a plant in Baltimore in the United States run by Emergent BioSolutions (EBS.N) have both been authorised by the drugs' regulator as a manufacturer of ingredients for the vaccines.
column16: Earlier this year, some EU countries raised questions about J&J's production network and contract with the EU, which would require it to send vaccines made at the Dutch factory to the United States for bottling before being shipped back to the EU.
column17: News that the EU had approved Johnson & Johnson's vaccine came as Norway and Denmark temporarily suspended the use of AstraZeneca's vaccine after reports of the formation of blood clots in some who have been vaccinated. read more
column19: TRIAL DATA
column20: In J&J's 44,000-person global trial, the vaccine was found to be 66% effective at preventing moderate-to-severe COVID-19 four weeks after inoculation. It was 100% effective in preventing hospitalization and death due to the virus. read more
column21: In its statement on Thursday, the EMA said the vaccine was found to be 67% effective two weeks after inoculation.
column22: The side effects were usually mild or moderate and cleared within a couple of days after vaccination, it said. The most common ones were pain at the injection site, headache, tiredness, muscle pain and nausea.
column23: Though many rival shots have reported a higher protection rate, J&J's vaccine could help boost thin EU supplies and simplify inoculation campaigns because it does not require a second dose or need to be shipped frozen.
column24: Direct comparison between headline numbers reported by different drugmakers is difficult because their trials had different goals, and J&J's study was conducted while new, more contagious variants of the virus were circulating.
column25: Its vaccine delivers instructions for human cells to manufacture immunity-building proteins, using a weakened version of a common-cold virus to carry them in, similar to AstraZeneca's shot, which uses a chimpanzee cold virus. J&J has also used the technology in its EU-approved Ebola vaccine.
column26: EU conditional marketing authorisation allows a treatment to be sold for a year without full data on its efficacy and side-effects being available.

column4: Biden says Americans will be first to get vaccines; any surplus to be shared
column5: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The U.S. government will first give Americans COVID-19 vaccines, but any surplus would be shared with the world, President Joe Biden said on Wednesday after earlier announcing plans to procure an additional 100 million doses.
column6: “We’re going to start off and ensure Americans are taken care of first, but we’re then going to try to help the rest of the world,” Biden told reporters following an earlier announcement to secure more vaccines with the chief executives of Johnson & Johnson and Merck.
column7: “If we have a surplus, we’re going to share it with the rest of the world,” Biden said, adding that the United States had already committed to providing $4 billion to the COVAX global initiative to distribute vaccines in developing countries.
column8: The Democratic president said it was clear that the pandemic would not be over until it was ended everywhere.
column9: “We’re not going to be ultimately safe, until the world is safe,” he said.
column10: White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki told reporters that Biden was deeply focused on expanding global vaccinations, but the U.S. government was pushing to first ensure sufficient doses for people in the United States who wanted to get vaccinated.
column11: She said Biden was discussing the need to ensure vaccines got to developing countries with his counterparts, but gave no details.
column12: The United States, Britain, European Union nations and other richer members of the World Trade Organization (WTO) on Wednesday blocked a push by more than 80 developing countries to waive patent rights in an effort to boost production of COVID-19 vaccines for poor nations.
column13: South Africa and India are leading the push for a temporary waiver of the rules of the WTO’s Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property (TRIPS) agreement, a move that could allow generic or other manufacturers to make more vaccines.
column14: Western nations argue that protecting intellectual property rights encourages research and innovation, and suspending those rights would not result in a sudden surge of vaccine supply.

column4: Biden prepares for 'challenges' with extra 100 million doses of J&J COVID-19 vaccine
column5: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - President Joe Biden on Wednesday directed his administration to procure 100 million more doses of the single-shot Johnson & Johnson coronavirus vaccine to boost U.S. supply in the event of “unexpected challenges” in the pandemic.
column6: The White House order comes as it seeks to speed up the process of inoculating people to curb the spread of COVID-19, which has killed more than 528,000 people in the United States alone.
column7: Biden highlighted the move at a meeting with the chief executives of J&J and Merck & Co. Merck has agreed to partner with J&J to produce its vaccine.
column8: “We need maximum flexibility. There’s always a chance that we’ll encounter unexpected challenges,” Biden said. “A lot can happen, a lot can change, and we need to be prepared.”
column9: The president has said previously that the United States will have enough supplies to vaccinate the U.S. population by the end of May.
column10: But the White House is eager to have more on hand.
column11: If the country had additional supply, it would be shared, Biden said. “If we have a surplus, we’re going to share it with the rest of the world,” he said.
column12: The United States has already paid over $1 billion for 100 million doses from J&J and had an option to purchase an additional 200 million doses.
column13: As of Tuesday morning, nearly 128 million doses of coronavirus vaccines from the three authorized providers have been distributed in the United States and nearly 96 million shots administered, according to data from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
column14: But J&J’s manufacturing has been slower than hoped, and it was not expected to deliver any vaccine doses this week. It is expected to resume shipments later in March.
column15: A J&J spokesman, Jake Sargent, said the company was on track to deliver the first 100 million doses of the vaccine ordered by the United States, but the company has come up short on its shipments this month, and expects to deliver only 20 million of the 37 million doses it had originally promised to have ready by now.
column16: Merck, meanwhile, will help with the final manufacturing steps called fill and finish - expected to be up and running in May - and production of the vaccine itself. J&J, which has committed to producing 1 billion doses this year, also said it is continuing to seek more manufacturing partners.
column17: CDC Director Rochelle Walensky said the recent plateau of COVID-19 cases appeared to be trending downward, while new hospital admissions and coronavirus-related deaths were also decreasing.
column18: “While these trends are starting to head in the right direction, the number of cases, hospitalizations and deaths still remain too high and are somber reminders that we must remain vigilant as we work to scale up our vaccination efforts across this country,” she said.
column19: The United States approved the Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna Inc vaccines in December, and those companies have been working to increase their production since then.
column20: Pfizer and Moderna have committed to supplying the country with 120 million doses and 100 million doses, respectively, by the end of March. They have agreed to supply 300 million doses each by the end of July.
column21: “We want to be oversupplied and overprepared,” White House spokeswoman Jen Psaki said earlier on Wednesday.

column4: U.S. administers 95.7 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines: CDC
column5: The United States has administered 95,721,290 doses of COVID-19 vaccines in the country and distributed 127,869,155 doses as of Wednesday morning, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Wednesday.
column6: The tally is for Moderna, Pfizer/BioNTech, and Johnson & Johnson’s vaccines as of 6:00 a.m. ET on Wednesday, the agency said.
column7: According to the tally posted on March 9, the agency had administered 93,692,598 doses of the vaccines, and distributed 123,232,775 doses.
column8: The agency said 62,451,150 people had received at least one dose, while 32,904,161 people were fully vaccinated.
column9: A total of 7,445,798 vaccine doses have been administered in long-term care facilities, the agency said.
